Reviews.Title: Jitterbug is Just
Reviews.Author: Linda Hanson
Reviews.Content: I ordered the Jitterbug J Cell Phone (Red) for my Mom.  She absolutely does not know how to use anything...cell phone, cd player, computer.  This phone is perfect for her.  All she has to do is open it, arrow up or down to the person she wants to call, and push call. She loves it.  The phone came in perfect condition at a much, much lower price than if purchased from a retail store in person.  It is easily set up with easy to read instructions and easily accessible "real people help" if you need to call.Anyone technologically challenged who wants a cell phone just for calling, or wants one for a loved one in the same situation should seriously consider Jitterbug.  Consumer Cellular has a great deal, but their service is spotty, and there were numerous dead spots when using their phone. Jitterbug has no problems.  I was a skeptic, but this phone has proven me wrong.

Reviews.Title: Not Good.
Reviews.Author: C. Sahu "Cathy Sahu"
Reviews.Content: I got this phone for my brother, who's an invalid. Luckily, I decided to charge and activate the phone before giving it to him.When I received the Jitterbug, I plugged it in to charge it. After a few hours the screen said, "Charge completed." So I unplugged and called GreatCalls to have the phone activated.The operator picked up in about a minute. (Good.) But already I could tell the reception was poor - I couldn't hear every other word or so. The operator told me it was because I hadn't charge the battery long enough - even though the screen said, "Charge complete," I should charge it for 12 hours. (I thought he sounded a little irritable, but maybe that was my imagination. He did, after all, have to repeat himself because of the bad connection.)So I plugged the phone back into the charger. The next day, after more than 12 hours of charging, when I again called GreatCalls to activate the phone, it continued to crackle and then lost the call altogether.I called GreatCalls back because, even though I was pretty sure at this point that the phone needed to be returned, I wanted to check if they had any more words of wisdom. Once again, the phone reception was breaking up - both for me and for the operator. So she took my other cell phone number and called me there. I explained everything I've written above but the lady said, "Oh, I'm sure the phone is fine. I think the problem is on my end. Let me help you activate the phone."I pointed out that she was the third operator I had spoken to and that, last time, the phone had dropped the call altogether. She continued to insist that the phone was fine: "It's my headset. There's something wrong with it."I pointed out that she was talking to me just fine with her headset on my other cell phone! She didn't have an argument for that but still wanted to activate the Jitterbug!!I said, "No thanks, I don't want to activate." (I do have to admit that she was consistently polite.)So I'm returning the Jitterbug and not getting another one. If it were just a problem with the phone itself, I would probably have had it exchanged for another Jitterbug. The Jitterbug phone is actually made by Samsung and the cell tower service is through Verizon. That's how my own cell phone is and I've had no real problems with it.But I really felt that the operators just want to make the sale and don't care about what problems the customer might have afterwards. I mean, if I had given this phone directly to my brother, who's never had a cell phone, he might have believed what the nice lady said and let her activate it. Then, in an emergency, he wouldn't have been able to use it. Or, at some point, I would have asked my brother how the phone was working, and he'd have admitted he didn't use it because he couldn't hear, and I'd have had to return the phone anyway, after having paid for monthly service fee for who knows how long?Also, the first operator was just stringing me along, I think, by telling me the phone needed to be charged 12 hours. Why would incomplete charging cause the transmission to crackle? Neither operator admitted that there might be something wrong with the phone.And we live in Southern California, well within Verizon service territory, so it couldn't have been a problem with that.

Reviews.Title: Great for ease of use and Seniors
Reviews.Author: Andee
Reviews.Content: I bought for my Aunt who is in her 80's, it is her first cellphone. She loves the phone although it is a little bigger than I thought it would be. The Jitterbug people are so nice and are available 24/7. I was able to completely program all the numbers on my computer for her on her phone.The phone has a speaker button and is loud so that's good. There is no 911 button. She would have to dial 911 then hit send. Not sure if that would present a problem in an emergency. The gray button on the outside should be removed it is just to change the volume but she accidently hits it sometimes. It should really be on the side like a regular cellphone.All in all, definitely great to have instead of/or with an emergency button.

Reviews.Title: Great Phone for Elderly Parent
Reviews.Author: curly "zatman"
Reviews.Content: My mom loves it! No more accidentally getting on the web or getting lost in setups & apps. The screen is easy to see & the only options are "Yes" or "No". The customer service is just excellent (e.g. no foreign accents & positive, friendly attitudes (great if mom ever needs to call them)).  I like that her contacts can be setup on the web, so she just calls me when she wants to add new contacts. It's very important to take care of elderly parents, life ain't all about you.

Reviews.Title: Best phone ever for the "cell phone challenged"
Reviews.Author: Susan2
Reviews.Content: I bought this phone for my 87 year old mother who could not master a regular cell phone. She could never manage to find her contacts and kept shutting it off by holding the off button down. This phone on the other hand is so easy to understand. Instead of "on & off" the main buttons are "yes and no". A simple arrow down brings up the contacts. But the best part of all is the real live customer service person available 24 hours a day. She very patiently set up my mom's phone. She didn't even have to input her own contacts. They did this for her. If she forgets how to call me, she can just push the "yes" botton twice and it will ring my phone. Plans can be changed at any time to add more minutes and I can do this for her from my computer or she can just call customer service anytime. The phone is large enough for the numbers to be easily read and pushed but small enough to carry around. This was an excellent purchase and I saved $30 by buying it from Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Review based on usage by 85-year-old man...
Reviews.Author: Amber
Reviews.Content: I don't use this phone... it's for my grandfather who is terrible with electronics.  Ok, it works, gets good reception, etc.  The biggest problem with it is that rocker button on the front outside.  It controls the volume ONLY when the phone is open.  What a dumb design.  For some reason, he ends up hitting the button and eventually turning it to vibrate/silent and never notices until one of the other relatives complains they can't reach him.  Make sure your technically-challenged user knows how to use a rocker-style button... that took a little explaining.

Reviews.Title: SERVICE IS AWFUL!
Reviews.Author: Diane Chin
Reviews.Content: This purchase has given us nothing but trouble! We ordered the Jitterbug for our 87-year-old aunt to use when the power fails or she can't easily get out of her chair to make a call. First problem: the manual says "charge for 12 hours before using" and the phone's screen says "charge complete" in just a couple hours. Second problem: when we called to activate the phone (we gave it 12+ hours), the service rep was fumbling, confused and confusing. Very poor, even somewhat rude, communication on his part which I ascribe to poor training and inadequate monitoring. Third problem: we were surprised by the activation fee of $39.63, which I don't remember reading in the sales pitch for the Jitterbug. If it's stated, it's not prominently mentioned. Fourth problem: the "phonebook" function is not working properly. No matter which selection we make, the phone calls the SAME number. Four calls to customer service yielded four different solutions, none of which worked.  Fifth problem: when I woke up yesterday, I discovered the service provider had charged that darn activation fee to our debit card FOUR TIMES for a total of $158.52! So now we have another headache. If I had it to do over again, I sure wouldn't purchase this phone.The technology isn't reliable and the customer service is unspeakably bad.

Reviews.Title: Jitterbug Red Cel Phone
Reviews.Author: Sunshine 2066
Reviews.Content: I bought this phone for my Aunt who is 87.  She is in a Nursing Home and this phone give her the ability to move around and still be in contact with family and friends.The colour (red) is bright enough for her to find and the numbers are large enough for her to see to dial.The fact that she can reach a live person at any time is a big plus.I would recommend this phone to Seniors or anyone who has difficult seeing the numbers on a cell phone and who wants the assurance of help by just pressing a button.

Reviews.Title: Does the job, but disappointing
Reviews.Author: R. McDonald
Reviews.Content: The conceit of this phone is that it's easy for an elderly person to use. I would say that it is *possible* for an elderly person to use it, but I would not say it was easy for my mom. The design takes a lot for granted and is not intuitive for someone coming from a traditional corded or cordless phone. If you're buying this for someone elderly who isn't used to small/mobile phones, do not expect them to understand it quickly. But there's a good chance they'll get it eventually.First, when someone who is elderly/confused opens the phone, which end is up? For the first week, my mom had a 50/50 chance of putting the microphone to her ear. (Note that a traditional phone has either a cord or antenna to orient you. If you leave this phone plugged in, it's easier to use.) Yes there's a keypad and screen, but the external cues are weak. In my mom's case, the phone proved confusing. You might say that's ridiculous, I'm just reporting what I saw.Second, the yes/no buttons and arrows are reasonably intuitive for someone used to navigating menu systems, but are not at all intuitive for someone who hasn't used a computer or modern mobile phone. And "yes" and "no"? This choice makes sense for some things, not for other things. (Ideally, you'd have buttons that changed text according to context, but I realize this would make the phone more expensive.) The good news is that my Mom is now able to make calls and answer the phone, but it took a while.Finally, despite what I was told when I activated the phone, the website will not allow you to change plans or add minutes. I spent a lot of time mucking around on the web site only to learn that you have to call customer service to do that. (There is now a pop up message to this effect.) And when I did call customer service to add minutes, I learned that the plan information I was seeing on the web was different than what the customer service person told me I had! In the end she was able to add minutes so the "official" system showed the same minutes as what was showing on the web, but it was pretty amateurish.Two pluses: The service plans are reasonable. And it's great that you can customize the phone menu from the web. Of course, you can do something like that for lots of phones these days, but it's still a very useful feature.Would I buy it again? Probably not. With hindsight the alternative of a traditional landline phone would have been smarter. It certainly would have been less stressful for everyone at the outset. And it might even have been less expensive.

Reviews.Title: Good for inexperienced phome users
Reviews.Author: pebarbdd
Reviews.Content: I bought the Jitterbug for my 91 year old mother.  The fact that it is so much like a regular phone was very helpful to her.  She needs it because she still drives.  Also, since we have frequent power outages this time of year, it comes in handy to keep in touch.  Delivery and set up were easy too.

Reviews.Title: Volume
Reviews.Author: Chris Vaccari
Reviews.Content: Volume control is awful can barely hear on this phone . Purchased this for an elderly person who is hard of hearing so it will really be a challange

Reviews.Title: Safety phone
Reviews.Author: John J. Hallowell
Reviews.Content: Pros: great all the way except...Cons: The phone does not have a vibrate mode. My father in law is very hard of hearing and does not hear the phone ring, even when it is in his pocket. I have never seen a phone before this one, which is touted as being a safety device, that came without a vibration mode. This is a big Con in my book,

Reviews.Title: Phone is well designed; its features...not so much
Reviews.Author: Free Spirit
Reviews.Content: I wanted a fairly basic cell phone with easy to push buttons, good coverage, strong customer support, phone book, voice mail, and no contracts.  My experience with their customer support has been good so far, but I haven't used it much.  I was very impressed with their coverage map, and so far I've not run into any dead zones.  On the other hand, I'm told that my reception is only "Fair" a lot more often than I expected in a well-populated area.  I am 60 and this is, I believe, my fourth cell phone.  I do love the large buttons.  I find that choosing between yes and no doesn't always make sense for what you are trying to do, but neither do the equivalent options on most phones.  Two buttons, whatever they are labeled, just don't fit all situations.  But this is something you will most likely get used to.I think there is much to like about this phone, so I'm very disappointed that it also has a number of significant drawbacks that will probably have me moving on to another phone in a year or two:- I was beyond disappointed (ie, stunned) to find that the names you enter into the phonebook are listed in tne order of entry, not alphabetically.  This means you have to laboriously scroll through up to 50 names to find the one you want to call. Surely this must be difficult for arthritic fingers, which I am fortunate not to have so far.  I expect Great Call's thought is that you can just call Customer Service and have them dial the number for you. I can't imagine anyone wanting to be in situation where they have call a third party every time they want to make a phone call, any more than they would want to have to scroll through a whole lot of numbers first.  (You just want to pick up the phone and call.)  Presumably some users are sufficiently challenged that this is the best they can do, but...these folks are probably not going to use the phonebook anyway.  So, if you are going to HAVE a phonebook, you want to be able to find names in it easily.  I still can't believe they aren't alphabetized.  This is such a no-brainer, and, given that every other cell phone I've ever had or used stored the names alphabetically, it can't be all that hard.- If you enter more than the maximum 50 names in the phone book, the phone just deletes one to make room for #51, instead of telling you that you are at max and letting YOU decide if you want to delete one of the existing numbers (and WHICH number you want to delete).  I'm thinking it is probably first in/first out, so probably the number that is deleted is the one that was so important to you, you entered it first of all.  This phone will last with me until the day I look for a number and find it's been deleted. Then it's in the trash.- You can't tell if the phone is on standby or off.  This is kind of ironic, because every time you call customer service, they make a point of urging you to keep your phone on at all times.  I find myself checking it several times throughout the day, and I would think people who are not accustomed to having a cell phone would be constantly checking it to make sure it is on.This will be a good choice for some people, no doubt.  For me, it's one of those "If only...." situations. I would love it if the features were as well designed as the phone itself.  But they aren't.

Reviews.Title: Great Product! Terrible phone company....
Reviews.Author: GBAhunter
Reviews.Content: Purchased this for my grandma (Not good with electronics) and she has figured it out just fine. So far the product itself has performed just fine.As for calling to activate the phone... well that didn't go so well. First off they outsourced the people you have to call so you can't understand their english.. But other than that I did all the talking for my grandma who is older and has a harder time hearing on the phone. But the guy on the phone kept on insisting to talk to her and kept on trying to get her to add more minutes, add long distance, buy a case, buy another charger... etc. he would not stop trying to get her to buy more, and would not talk to me.. The one setting the phone up! Very disappointed in the phone company trying to take advantage of the elderly, I know that it's good business to suggestion sell, but to try and force it and keep asking is another thing..

Reviews.Title: But Wait there's more....
Reviews.Author: SDrunner
Reviews.Content: Please be aware that if you already have Sprint, Verizon, or AT&T; service you will be required by Jitterbug to buy additional cell phone service plus a hefty activation fee. They don't make this clear when purchasing the phone. Jitterbug only leases Verizon cell towers but the cell phone service itself is not carried by Verizon so the Jitterbug is incompatible with your current plan with Verizon. No where on this site does it expressly say you must buy additional coverage through Jitterbug. I returned the phone.

Reviews.Title: AWESOME!!  EXCELLENT CHOICE FOR SENIORS!!
Reviews.Author: LG
Reviews.Content: First of all, in my humble opinion, this phone seems to be the type of phone that is custom made for seniors, disabled seniors, or disabled individuals only. That said, I was more than delighted when I received this phone which, luckily for me, was on a promo which discounted the pricey 99.00 Jitterbug J to 50%.  I do object to the pricey plans re: the Unlimited 24/7 free minutes plan is a whopping $79.00 a month and so I had to go for the Premium plan which is $39.00 for 400 weekday minutes until 7 pm-5 am in which it's free and unlimited weekends.  For me, it's not that bad because I am not a chatty type but if I feel like having a long conversation with someone I can save it for the evenings and weekends. Also the minutes are roll-over minutes for 60 days.  The only other cons are 1) the customer service reps are quite young and impatient, seemingly not trained to understand senior issues, and 2)the speakerphone could be louder. Speaker phone is a big need for me because I have severe chronic pain issues and have trouble with holding the phone. If I DO hold the phone, it's nice to have those grippers on the side so that the sleek phone does not slip out of  my hand. The last con is voice dial. I love that also because it is totally hands free to call anyone in your address book.  However when you tell the phone the name, it repeats it back in an almost unintelligible way.  Eventually you get used to the mispronunciation.  I feel as if all the people that are complaining just don't get the concept of the Jitterbug.  It is PERFECTLY designed for disabled, ill, or elderly people who have health issues. I have weak sight, practically crippled in the shoulders and arms and those other cell phones were all but impossible for me to understand or use. On Jitterbug J you can even dial a LIVE operator 24/7 to help you to plan events for your calender.  They have a MedCoach app that is saving my life by giving me reminder calls to take my many meds.  It also will call you when your refills are due and even call the pharmacy number for you!!  I have SEVERE short term memory loss and previously forgot to take my meds and refill them which created a few dangerous health episodes. If you are younger and expecting a phone with fun features and lots of variety, it will not be for you.  I also find the ringer to be quite loud enough. My phone is bright red and it keeps me from losing it.  Also, there IS a whole different way of programming this phone and it is a bit annoying at first but once you get the hang of it, it's smooth sailing and unbelievably easy.  I absolutely LOVE this phone and plan to be with GreatCall for the rest of my life but do not recommend it to people who are young and healthy.  It's perfect for anyone with vision issues, problems with shoulder, arm, and hand mobility, and short term memory loss.  It's also comforting to know that there is always someone to call in Customer Service 24 hours a day for free even if they are not trained well. Jitterbug rocks.

Reviews.Title: Don't buy this phone!
Reviews.Author: Jane Levine
Reviews.Content: The provider gave out ALL of my personal info! Now I am getting harrassing calls. I have had this phone for months, just to call 911, if I need help in my car. I have never used it once, or given the number out to Anyone! They promised to send me a free car charger. I never received it. I pay extra to have a blocked number. I'm going to cancel the service, and take my chances in the car.

Reviews.Title: Love my Jitterbug!
Reviews.Author: Judy
Reviews.Content: Very nicely designed and easy to use. Here in NJ, there were places where I couldn't get a signal with my previous cell phone, but my Jitterbug works fine everywhere I go. I purchased my Jitterbug from Amazon but had no trouble getting it activated through GreatCall. GreatCall's customer service has been very good. This is a no-contract phone, so I can easily cancel if they don't give me good service, but so far I've been very happy with both the phone and the service.

Reviews.Title: Jitterbug J
Reviews.Author: mbl8844
Reviews.Content: A beautifully simple phone with straight forward operation. Nice menu system for first time cell phone owners. Large display, large numbers and buttons makes for easy operation.  The "5 star" system is easy to set up and a great piece of mind  emergency system.  The 5 star emergency response system for active adults, not just restricted to your home, with gps bringing responders to your location when needed. Great service and call quality.

Reviews.Title: Finally a phone that does what a phone is supposed to do.
Reviews.Author: Philip R. HUGHES "Capri142"
Reviews.Content: First off I want to say that having read a good many of the other reviews here, I am surpeised at the number of negative ones that have nothing to do with the phone but the user. It is a Cell Phone and as such there vis a learning curve.  That said this is a simple phone that does what it is supposed to do, make phone calls. I am not an old guy (yet) but I don't need a phone that does everything but cook my breakfast for me. If I want to chek my banki account online, read a book, play games, surf the web, etc, etc, etc, I'll use my Laptop, PC or iPAD. If I want to take pictures, I'll use my camera.  The Jitterbug makes great call and the volume (despite what other posters have said) CAN be adjusted til it is almost too loud. The large buttons accommodate my large fingers nicely. As a Motorcycle rider, the Star5 plan is awesome. If I go down on a remote road or slip and fall while alone in the house, they can send the rescue to my location. Can you get that for 14 bucks with your smart phone?  Someone here complained that only 50 names in the directory is not enough. such silliness. I don't know anyone who calls 50 different people. If you need more than that get an address book.  The Customer service is the best of any phone company that I have ever called. Call AT&T; or Comcast and you get stuck in the dreaded recorded message loop with ever other message directing you to the website which can "answer all your questions". At Jitterbug. I have never had to wait more than 15 seconds before a real person came on the phone. A person who could speak plain English and my questions/issues were resolved with the first call.  If you are looking for a phone that does what it is supposed to do, that won't lock you into a contract and has reasonably priced plans, I would suggest you give the Jitterbug a try  Just don't expect it to do much more than be a darned good little telephone.

Reviews.Title: does what it should
Reviews.Author: mommommom
Reviews.Content: it does what it should... the numbers are large and its not confusing.... nothing unnecessary.... however its unclear how to get back to the home screen without shutting the phone off and back on

Reviews.Title: sad ending
Reviews.Author: Betty Hamilton "betaham"
Reviews.Content: I had a jitterbug for several years then got a cell phone and called to end my services with Jitterbug, they said they would and nothing more needed to be done. Now almost a year later I am being badgered with phone calls saying I owe them money! Is their business so bad these days they have to stoop to such methods. I do not owe them anything and have told them but they keep on calling me! Bad ending to an otherwise good experience, oh I forgot many times their reporting on how many callshad left was never accurate. So that was not good either!

Reviews.Title: Cell Phone for 95 Year Old
Reviews.Author: Murray S. Wood
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Jitterbug for my 95 year old mother. At first she was intimidated but after she got over the applications such as "Phone Book" and "Call History" and thought of it as a regular phone, she was comfortable with it. Had to turn the volume and ringer up to full volume due to hard of hearing.

Reviews.Title: Rip off
Reviews.Author: Ira Rosen
Reviews.Content: Company refused to close my account without charging an extra month.  Their policy is to squeeze an extra payment out of you.My policy is to not pay for services I don't want!

Reviews.Title: love this!
Reviews.Author: quality matters
Reviews.Content: got the jitterbug, now GreatCall, because of the service offered for seniors, etc--  mom loves her 'little red phone' with big print & easy to use instructions--  of course, it works only with the GreatCall service-

Reviews.Title: SAY NO TO JITTERBUG
Reviews.Author: Joan Milano
Reviews.Content: I HAD THE JITTERBUG TOUCH 1  (SMARTPHONE) WELL IT WAS RETURNEDAND IT IS NOT EASY TO USE.  THIS COMPANY IS VERY COSTLY STARTING WITH THEIR PHONES, ACTIVATION FEE (35.00!!!!) YOU PAY SHIPPING TO RETURN AND A  10.00!!!  RE STOCKING FEE.  YOU ALSO PAY EXTRA FOR THEIR MEDICAL ALERT DEPENDING ON THE PLAN.  I WILL NOT RECOMENDJITTERBUG TO ANYONE GO ELSE WHERE FOR A PHONE.  CONSUMER CELLULAR DOES NOT GET YOU FOR ALL THESE CHARGES.

Reviews.Title: Jitterbug
Reviews.Author: Deanna E. French
Reviews.Content: This product was just the thing for my elderly mom who doesn't use a cell phone very much but needed one for emergency purposes.

Reviews.Title: IN LOVE WITH MY JITTERBUG
Reviews.Author: genieoutofthebottle
Reviews.Content: When I found smart phones "too smart" for me, I decided to try the Jitterbug J Cell Phone.  It has simplified my life, given me exactly what I really need in a phone, and I love it!  With a choice of additional aps, it more than compensates for what I had been using.  I highly recommend it!

Reviews.Title: The Jitterbug
Reviews.Author: VJ
Reviews.Content: This phone has been ideal for an older adult with vision and hearing difficulties; It's easy to use, has an easy to read face, and has health options that provide a measure of security.  It also has a nice long battery life.

Reviews.Title: Great phone
Reviews.Author: Marion Librarian
Reviews.Content: I got this phone for my 86 year old mother and she really likes it. Arrived quickly and looks great.

Reviews.Title: PRACTICAL CELL PHONE
Reviews.Author: C. Polewaski "goldring"
Reviews.Content: The Jitterbug is an excellent cell phone. Easy to see and operate.Be aware you have a start up fee beside the plan fee.But the plans are flexible.My mother at 86 with hearing and eyesight problems is able to use it.A no nonsence cell phone...........................

Reviews.Title: Stay FAR AWAY from this phone and the Great Call Company!!!!
Reviews.Author: BJESC "Teacher Meanie"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this for my elderly parents in Oct2013. It couldn't be activated properly by the Great Call company and yet I was charged the Activation Fee and Monthly Fees for Nov. and Dec. Three days before visiting my folks in Chicago, my mom misplaced the non-functioning Jitterbug phone...little wonder. I bought a new one for my folks and was, stupidly, talked into purchasing a monthly "phone replacement" fee of $4. In addition, I paid for an expedited shipping fee, which took several days for the phone to get from Libertyville, IL to Chicago, IL when I was promised that it was to be only 2 days. Finally, charged the phone only to find out that the Great Call rep activated the wrong phone. Then I was told by another rep that it would only take an hour for the old phone to be "unactivated" and for the new one to get activated. Called again since the activation process STILL didn't work and was told by another rep that the activation process would take another 24 hours at which this time I told Great Call that I was quite fed up with their poor business practices and customer service and to just cancel the entire service and refund my money. I was to return their phone to them only to get the purchase price after 21 BUSINESS DAYS!!! Really? I am reporting this company to the IL BBB and to the IL State Attorney General's Office as a scam company that preys on the elderly.

Reviews.Title: phone was obsolete
Reviews.Author: wayne parenteau
Reviews.Content: The phone was an obsolete model and because it was outdated Jitterbug would not activate it. However I do like the phone and I wish there was a carrier that would service it. I did receive a refund and was told to keep the phone.

Reviews.Title: A great phone, easy to use.
Reviews.Author: S Long
Reviews.Content: This is my first and I hope only cell phone.  It works well and is very sturdy.  I wanted just a 'quality' phone with no other programming to wade through

Reviews.Title: Great phone for my Dad
Reviews.Author: Steve Durko
Reviews.Content: My Dad was not using the cell phones that we bought him because the controls were too small and there were too many options.  The Jitterbug solves that problem with a simplified interface that is pretty simple to work with.  Also live support works with them to find numbers or add people.  Only downside I heard was that the ringer could be a little louder, but it was not to bad.-Steve Durko

Reviews.Title: Save your money!
Reviews.Author: xaipe
Reviews.Content: I bought a Samsung brand phone from Jitterbug and it can only be characterized as CRAP. It only holds a charge for a short time so I am constantly re-charging. Calls are frequently dropped even though I live in an urban area which should have good reception. The phone only rings when someone is calling me about 1/4 of the time, calls go to voice mail even if I am sitting next to the silent phone. Calls almost always have static. You must pay extra for voice mail, and there is a separate charge if you take photos. You have to pay to retrieve them. I'm dropping this so-called service. if I could have given Jitterbug less than a 1 star rating I would have. SAVE YOUR MONEY!

Reviews.Title: Jitterbug J Cell Red Phone
Reviews.Author: tibetanterriermama
Reviews.Content: This phone is for people like me who don't understand a lot of technical things so need working simplicity which this phone does provide.  Like big numbers and size......holds charge for a long time.  Only use for emergencies, not to gab.

Reviews.Title: Guess I can't "Jitterbug" with you,  Amazon
Reviews.Author: Island rose
Reviews.Content: 8/27/12  All went well and on schedule through Amazon's product purchase, delivery,and arrival service.  Great Call's set up service, excellent.  I had read about the "Jitterbug" a few years back and when I decided I would try to live my retired days with cell service only the "Jitterbug" was my choice. My Verizon phone is getting old but gets fairly good service on the island and I thought I read somewhere that "Jitterbug" operated over the Verizon network. But my little red phone's capability was poor giving me dropped/lost service calls.  I love the phone and would like to know how I could use the "Jitterbug" as a verizon serviced phone or how to return a new "Jitterbug" phone in "unopened condition" as the label states when I have had to use it to find out it doesn't work for me here, now.  Can anyone help???

Reviews.Title: There are Smart phones and there are dumb phones
Reviews.Author: Larry Richardson "L. Rich"
Reviews.Content: My wife and I are both in our 60's and had our cell service with AT&T; for years, but we lost thousands of minutes each year because we don't make that many calls. Long story short we made the switch to Jitterbug about 4 months ago. We went with the Jitterbug plus. First the good news. The telephone feature is adequate if all you want to do with this phone is make a call every now and then. The customer service has always been helpful to us, even though they haven't always been on the same page, and the monthly cost is very good. So much for the good news. After about a week the mic on my phone just stopped working. No, I hadn't dropped it or allowed it to get wet. Greatcalls said they'd send a new one at no charge since it was within the 90 day warranty. The phone arrived and I called to activate the new one. The service rep may not have understood the specifics, but he told me to just keep the old phone even though the paperwork with the new phone said to send it back. I decided to send it back using the return label that came with the new one. When the next bill came I had been charged $99 for the new phone! I called Customer Service to get the charge removed and was told they couldn't locate the returned phone. After talking to a supervisor I was told that they would eliminate the $99 charge, which they did. Now as for the phone itself. Calling is not a major problem, but texting is terrible. First there is a limit to how many texts the phone will hold. This information was nowhere in the sales info. Customer service told me that they thought the phone would only hold 20 texts, so if you haven't deleted texts in a day or two, any texts after number 20 are never received. What's even worse is that there is no notification or tracking when you have reached the max. Additionally, the phone doesn't have t9 texting, ugh, and you can only send a text to one person at a time. Once it's sent you have to retype it to send it to someone else. Probably the worst feature is what happens if you are in the process of texting and you receive a text at that moment......which happens a lot if you're carrying on a text conversation. When that happens the text you are typing immediately changes into numbers and asks if you want to make a call! To continue you first have to reject the incoming text, then jump through two more hoops. Trust me, the texting feature is a mess. If you want a very basic phone to make calls, this will do, but anything beyond that is just such low technology that it's more trouble than it's worth. We will be changing our service very soon.

Reviews.Title: Horrible Experience /With Five Star
Reviews.Author: Marie
Reviews.Content: The 5star service is horrible.The medical tech was totally untrained (kept me on hold most of the time) Would not confer with me at all just screamed at me and told me she was going to send an ambulance to my home whether I liked it or not.  All I wanted was to ask a nurse about a medication.  It was a horrible horrible transaction.  I will never call 5star again for a medical need.  Otherwise the phone is okay, except there is no place to hook it to a neck  chain. I finally got 911 stopped fron coming over. They were also very rude.

Reviews.Title: Another Lousy Product advertised  in  AARP  mag
Reviews.Author: Rimrock
Reviews.Content: After reading all the reviews on this site I have concluded that this is another product that AARP allowed to advertise in their magazine but has issues.It has been years now since I bought something advertised in the magazine but the time that I did I had to return the product.The magazine is like all others, they just need the revenue.  Which reminds me that after writing to AARP to complain the answer I got was they can't screen all their advertisers.  You would think that an organization dedicated to seniors would be looking out for us.  NOT!I just use the membership to get discounts when I travel and nothing else.  Sorry some of that money pays for lobbyists.BUYER BE WARE.  What sounds too good to be true probably is.
